  []PREFACE

  Assam, the gateway to Northeast India, is renowned for its vast tea gardens, the mighty Brahmaputra, rich biodiversity, and vibrant cultural heritage. The state is home to 18 wildlife sanctuaries and 7 national parks. Assam’s economy is deeply intertwined with its environment, making it highly vulnerable to climate change. Rising global temperatures have had a severe impact, with Climate Vulnerability Assessment for Adaptation Planning in India using a Common Framework report identifying 25 districts in Assam among the 100 most climate-vulnerable districts in India. The analysis further shows that approximately 90% of districts in Assam have a high level of vulnerability.

  To address these challenges, Assam has implemented robust frameworks, including the State Action Plan on Climate Change (SAPCC), the Disaster Risk Reduction (DRR) Roadmap 2030, the Assam Solar Energy Policy, 2017, and the Assam Electric Vehicle (EV) Policy, 2021, to mitigate environmental risks and promote sustainable development.

  Under the leadership of Hon’ble Chief Minister Dr. Himanta Biswa Sarma, Assam has taken significant steps to integrate climate action into its financial planning. Assam was the third state in India and the first in the Northeast to introduce Climate Budget Tagging in FY 2023-24, with other states following suit. The Green Budget serves as a critical tool to align government spending with climate and environmental sustainability goals.

  As a result of these concerted efforts, Assam’s Green Budget has seen steady growth. This year, 32 line departments participated in the Green Budget—more than double last year’s participation—with a total green budget allocation of

  ₹1,0138.75 crores, making up 11.35% of the combined budget of these departments.A well-defined methodology, comprehensive guidelines, and structured capacity- building programs have been instrumental in achieving this progress.

  The ‘Green Growth for Greener Assam’ initiative, under the ‘Astadash Mukutar Unnoyonee Mala’ of FY 2024-25, has introduced innovative interventions and made remarkable strides in sustainable development. A key achievement of Green Budgeting has been the significant increase in public procurement of greener alternatives, reaffirming Assam’s commitment to advancing Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

GREEN BUDGET IN ASSAM

FOR FY 2025-26

  For FY 2025-26, several green initiatives have been proposed in the Assam Assembly (detailed in Section IV). A major highlight is the approval of the Assam Integrated Clean Energy Policy, 2025, which focuses on solar power, wind energy, small hydro projects, pumped hydro storage, battery energy storage systems, green hydrogen, biofuels, and electric mobility.

  As we present the Green Budget for FY 2025-26, we reaffirm our commitment to integrating environmental and climate priorities into our fiscal policies. We also emphasize the need for robust monitoring mechanisms to track expenditures, assess the impact of green initiatives, and ensure accountability in achieving environmental sustainability objectives.

  Section I

  Introduction to Green Budgeting in Assam

  Green Budgeting is a strategic public finance management tool that ensures budgetary processes align with the state’s environmental and climate goals. By enabling the efficient allocation of resources, it reinforces Assam’s initiatives in climate change mitigation, climate change adaptation, and environmental sustainability while advancing multiple Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) such as SDG 13 (Climate Action), SDG 11 (Sustainable Cities and Communities), SDG 7 (Affordable and Clean Energy), and other SDGs, fostering a more sustainable and resilient future in line with the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and India’s Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) under the Paris Agreement and other national and state commitments, and aligning with India’s commitments under the Paris Agreement. In Assam, Green Budgeting has helped to:

  Streamline environmental sustainability and

  climate resilience into fiscal framework and governance

  Reinforce the need to look at public procurement from the ‘Green lens’

  -sustainable expenditure

  Encourage departments to align with national and international commitments towards climate change

  Enabled through Green budget, Guwahati Municipal Corporation piloted a 20 KLD Faecal Sludge Treatment Plan in Guwahati. The sustainable bio-resources based project leverages Upflow Anaerobic Sludge Blanket to treat sewage and contributes towards rejuvenation of Borsola Beel at Guwahati. This is a significant step towards the challenge of 130 MLD waste generation in Guwahati every day and exemplifies how green budgeting can drive innovative and sustainable solutions for urban challenges.

  This year, 18 departments have reported under the Green Budget Statement, in addition to the 14 that participated last year, marking more than a twofold increase from the previous year, covering nine vulnerable sectors to climate change as identified with Assam State Action Plan on Climate Change (ASAPCC). Section III 

Methodology for Green Budget Tagging for FY 2025-26

11

  GREEN BUDGET IN ASSAM

  FOR FY 2025-26

  The following steps have been followed for carrying out Green Budgeting in Assam in FY 2025-26:

  Step 1: Identification and selection of schemes by the departments

  Departments have identified and mapped budgetary allocations for schemes that directly or indirectly contribute to climate change mitigation, climate change adaptation, and environmental sustainability. The focus was on prioritising schemes with clear environmental objectives.

  [][][]Identification of four categories based on their impact on the environment

+-------------------------+------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+----------------------------------------------------------------+
|   Categories            |   Definition                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   |   Green Budget share                                           |
+=========================+:
|   Highly Favourable     |   The schemes where the principal intent is to address climate action and impact would fall under this category. These Schemes would bring highly favourable direct impact for the environment and climate change.                             |   100% of the allocation is towards Green Initiatives          |
+-------------------------+------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+----------------------------------------------------------------+
|   Moderately Favourable |   The schemes where the principal intent is not towards climate action but the impact is favorable towards climate action goals or environmental protection. These schemes would bring indirect impacts on the environment and climate change. |   At least 40% of the allocation is towards green initiatives  |
+-------------------------+------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+----------------------------------------------------------------+
|   Neutral               |   Schemes that do not target or not have a relevant impact for the environment and climate change.                                                                                                                                             |   Less than 40% of the allocation is towards green initiatives |
+-------------------------+------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+----------------------------------------------------------------+
|   Less favourable       |   Schemes that need improvement for climate action.                                                                                                                                                                                            |   No allocation towards green initiatives                      |
+-------------------------+------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+----------------------------------------------------------------+

12

  Step 2: Mentioning the scheme objectives

  Each department has clearly stated specific objectives for the identified schemes. This helped in assessing their relevance and impact on climate change and environmental sustainability.

Step 3: Selection of the broad domain

  Each scheme was categorised under one of the three broad domains, as per the Assam State Action Plan on Climate Change (ASAPCC).

  Explanation of three broad domains

+--------------------------------+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
|   Broad Domain                 |   Definition                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         |
+================================+:
|   Climate Change Adaptation    |   Schemes to reduce the impact of climate change, build capacity to withstand its effects, and reduce the potential for harm from climate change. These include Rain- fed Area Development, Erosion Protection, Early Warning Systems, among others.                                                                                                                                 |
+--------------------------------+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
|   Climate Change Mitigation    |   Schemes to combat (avoid and reduce) the root cause of climate change,                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             |
|                                |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      |
|                                |   i.e. emissions of greenhouse gases (GHG) into the atmosphere. These include transitioning to renewable energy sources, switching to regenerative agricultural practices, restoring forests, changes in our practices and behaviours, among others.                                                                                                                                 |
+--------------------------------+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
|   Environmental Sustainability |   Interventions targeted at sustainable use and protection of natural resources, transition to a circular economy, pollution prevention and control, and protection and restoration of biodiversity and ecosystem. These include Project Tiger, river conservation, waste management and prevention of air pollution, managing water pollution, wildlife conservation, among others. |
+--------------------------------+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+

13

  GREEN BUDGET IN ASSAM

  FOR FY 2025-26

Step 4: Selection of the sub-domain under broad domains

  Departments classified schemes under the following sub-domains to further enhance tracking and reporting.

1.  Climate Change Adaptation

    a.  Soil Conservation

    b.  Water Management & Ground Water Conservation

    c.  Preventing Erosion and Siltation

    d.  Disaster Management (including flood resilience) response

    e.  Disaster Management Resilience

    f.  Reduction of temperature variation

    g.  Sustainable Agriculture and Irrigation

    h.  Sustainable waste management, including e-waste

    i.  Sustainable housing and infrastructure

    j.  Sustainable livelihoods

    k.  Reduction of mortality and morbidity from climate change (impact on health)

2.  Climate Change Mitigation

    a.  Reduction of pollution and Green House Gas (GHG) Emissions

    b.  Promotion of renewable energy - Solar/ Hydro / Wind / Bio-gas

    c.  Promotion of public transport, including electric vehicles (EVs)

3.  Environmental Sustainability

    a.  Knowledge Building (Sensitisation, Capacity building, Training, Skill Development)

    b.  Operational Reforms (Green Budgeting, Green Public Procurement, etc))

    c.  Enhance environment awareness (government, youth, educational institutions, communities)

    d.  Enhance forest and tree cover

    e.  Protection of Wetlands, Springs, and Rivers

    f.  Preventing biodiversity loss

    g.  Preventing land and forest degradation

  Step 5: Remarks (mandatory for Highly Favourable and Moderately Favourable)

  Departments provided a brief rationale for classifying schemes as Highly Favourable or Moderately Favourable, including their expected environmental impact.

  Plantation programme under Amrit Brikhya Aandolon and Convergence - Handloom, Textile

  and Sericulture Department

  The scheme is a unique and significant afforestation initiative launched by the Government of Assam, inaugurated on June 8 2023, with its second edition beginning on August 1, 2024. A key objective of the program is to promote tree-based economic development. As part of this effort, the Directorate of Sericulture has planted silkworm host food plants across various government farms and private lands, covering 61.20 hectares, with regular maintenance carried out by the department. Additionally, through a convergence program with PNRD, the Directorate of Sericulture, Assam has planted 437.23 hectares of land over the past and current year, contributing to both environmental sustainability and economic development.

  Solar Powered Cart Mounted Multifunctional Irrigation Scheme - Irrigation Department

  The Solar-Powered Cart-Mounted Multifunctional Irrigation Scheme offers economic benefits to remote farmers by enhancing water efficiency, lowering costs, and boosting crop yields while supporting sustainable agriculture. Its portable design allows farmers to irrigate multiple areas without dependence on fixed infrastructure. The system effectively draws water from shallow tube wells or surface sources and includes quick-connect fittings, making it particularly beneficial in flood-prone regions. By utilizing solar energy, the initiative aims to maximize irrigation coverage with minimal resources and reduced construction costs.

  Mission Amrit Sarovar - Panchayat and Rural Development Department

  The Amrit Sarovar Initiative is a crucial initiative for water conservation and rural development, focused on restoring water bodies to address water scarcity and enhance rural livelihoods. By 2047, it is expected to significantly contribute to sustainable development and economic growth in India. The initiative supports water resource management by enabling groundwater recharge through the collection of rainwater and runoff, ensuring long-term water sustainability. Additionally, it fosters biodiversity by creating habitats for native plant and animal species while increasing green cover, thereby enhancing climate resilience in rural communities.

  24 MW Karbi Langpi Middle -II Hydro Power Project Assam Power Generation Corporation Limited (APGCL) - Power (Electricity) Department

  The 24 MW Karbi Langpi Middle-II Hydro Power Project, a Run of River scheme on the Umkhem/Borpani River in West Karbi Anglong, Assam, is being developed by APGCL and set for commissioning by 2027-28. Expected to generate 112.30 million units of clean energy annually, it will boost Assam’s renewable capacity, reduce carbon emissions and lessen dependence on fossil fuels, supporting sustainable energy development.

Section VI 

Key Insights from Green Budgeting in Assam for FY 2025-26

  The select departments were assessed using the said framework and their schemes were categorised into four groups: ‘Highly Favourable’, ‘Moderately Favourable’, ‘Neutral’, and ‘Less Favourable’ along with three broad domains - Climate Change Adaptation, Climate Change Mitigation and Environmental Sustainability, and 22 sub-domains. In the Green Budget exercise for FY 2025-26, 32 departments participated, with the Green Budget accounting for 11.35% of the combined budget of these 32 departments. For FY 2025-26, the majority of schemes and programmes implemented by these departments are focussed towards climate change adaptation. Around 173 schemes have been classified as highly favourable and 184 schemes are moderately favourable.

  []GREEN BUDGET IN ASSAM

  FOR FY 2025-26

  Key Insights from Green Budgeting (FY 2025-26)

1.  Agriculture Department

  The department has 43 highly favourable schemes such as State Mission for Millet and Pulses, National Mission on Natural Farming (NMNF), etc., 36 moderately favourable schemes such as Rastriya Krishi Vikash Yojana, Agriculture Information & Publicity, etc. and 39 neutral schemes viz. Development of Assam Agriculture University with focus on climate adaptation and environment sustainability aspects. The sub-domains broadly include - sustainable agriculture and irrigation, sustainable livelihoods, knowledge building (sensitisation, capacity building, training, skill development), disaster management (including flood resilience) response among others.

2.  Animal Husbandry and Veterinary Department

  The department has 4 highly favourable schemes such as Participation Of Exhibition & Exhibits, Cattle Development Programme, etc and 6 moderately favourable such as. Poultry Development Programme, Goatery Development Programme, Expansion of Piggery Development (Headquarters Establishment, Development Programme - Policy for Commercialisation of Poultry sector in Assam, 3 neutral schemes. The sub-domains broadly include knowledge building (sensitisation, capacity building, training, skill development), sustainable livelihoods, sustainable waste management, including e-waste, reduction of pollution and Green House Gas (GHG) emissions with climate change adaptation and environment and sustainability as the broad domain.

3.  Environment and Forest Department

  The department is implementing various schemes aimed at environmental sustainability. A total of 25 schemes fall under the highly favorable category, including initiatives like Project Tiger and Project Elephant, Plantation of Avenue Trees, etc. Additionally, 5 schemes are classified as moderately favourable such as remuneration for Gaonburahs in forest villages like Dayang and Tengani, as well as projects focused on advancing modern technologies and communication systems for forestry and wildlife conservation. Furthermore, 6 schemes are neutral including the construction of the Natural History Museum at Kaziranga and the Center-cum-Forest Museum at Manas and Joypur (Dehing-Patkai). The sub-domains broadly include - enhance forest and tree cover, prevent biodiversity loss, and mitigate land and forest degradation.

4.  Fisheries Department

  The department has 4 Highly favourable schemes such as. Fish and Fish seed Farming-Gene Bank For Protection and Conservation of Indigenous Fish Species in Assam, 6 moderately favourable and 4 neutral schemes with focus on climate adaptation, climate mitigation and environmental sustainability aspects of the state.. The sub-domains broadly include - reduction of pollution and Green House Gas (GHG) emissions, prevention of biodiversity loss, knowledge building (sensitisation, capacity building, training, skill development), disaster management resilience and protection of wetlands, springs, and rivers.

26

5.  []Handloom Textiles and Sericulture Department

  The department has reported 1 highly favourable scheme - Upkeeping of the Govt. Eri, Muga & Mulberry Farms. 10 moderately favourable schemes such as Handloom Training Institute & Centre-Self Employment to Passed Out Trainees, Assam Silk Outreach Mission(Muga), Handloom model village etc. The sub-domains broadly include sustainable livelihoods, knowledge building (sensitisation, capacity building, training, skill development), reduction of pollution and Green House Gas (GHG) emissions, preventing biodiversity loss, preventing land and forest degradation focusing on climate change adaptation and environment and sustainability as the broad domain.

6.  Health & Family Welfare Department

  The department has 1 highly favorable scheme - Bio-Medical Waste Management Programme. The sub-domain broadly includes -Sustainable waste management, including e-waste addressing Climate Change Adaptation broad domain.

7.  Medical Education & Research Department

  The department has 2 highly favourable scheme - Assam State Secondary Health Care Initiative for Service Delivery Transformation (ASSIST) and JICA ODA Strengthening Health Systems and Excellence of Medical Education in Assam, and 10 moderately favourable scheme - Establishment of Nursing Colleges at Lakhimpur, Kokrajhar, Diphu, Nagaon. Sub domains include - Sustainable livelihoods, Reduction of mortality and morbidity from climate change (impact on health), Knowledge Building (Sensitisation, Capacity building, Training, Skill Development), Sustainable housing and infrastructure, Reduction of pollution and Green House Gas (GHG) Emissions under the broad domains - Climate Adaptation and Environment sustainability

8.  Housing and Urban Affairs Department

  The department has 15 highly favourable schemes such as Swachh Bharat Mission, Guwahati Metropolitan Development Authority, Improvement of Infrastructure of Guwahati City, Street Light to ULBs, etc. Additionally 14 moderately favourable schemes have been reported such as Drainage Master plan for other Towns of State, AMRUT 2.0, etc and 23 neutral schemes.. The sub-domains broadly include - water management & ground water conservation, sustainable housing and infrastructure, reduction of temperature variation, reduction of mortality and morbidity from climate change (impact on health), disaster management resilience, reduction of pollution and Green House Gas (GHG) emissions, promotion of renewable energy - solar/ hydro / wind / bio, preventing erosion and siltation, disaster management (including flood resilience) response addressing all the three broad domains

  - climate change adaptation, mitigation and environment and sustainability.

27

  []GREEN BUDGET IN ASSAM

  FOR FY 2025-26

9.  Industries, Commerce and Public Enterprises Department

  The department has 9 highly favourable schemes, including the National Bamboo Mission (NBM) and Upgradation of Industrial Areas. Additionally, there are 15 moderately favourable schemes, such as the Raising and Accelerating MSME Performance (RAMP) Scheme, MASSI Grant, Administrative Expenses of Assam Hub, and the Agar International Trade Centre (AITC). Furthermore, 30 neutral schemes have been reported The sub-domains broadly include sustainable livelihoods, enhance forest and tree cover, reduction of pollution and Green House Gas (GHG) emissions, promotion of renewable energy - solar/ hydro / wind / bio, knowledge building (sensitisation, capacity building, training, skill Development).

10. Irrigation Department

  The department has 8 highly favourable schemes, including flow irrigation and tube well with solar system, along with 4 moderately favourable schemes, such as lift irrigation, PMKSY- HKKP-GW, and AIBP-SMI. These initiatives focus on climate adaptation and environment and sustainability. The sub-domains broadly include sustainable agriculture and irrigation while promoting the use of renewable energy sources like solar, hydro, wind, and bioenergy.

11. Panchayat and Rural Development Department

  The department has 4 highly favourable schemes viz. Housing for All (Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana), Central Finance Commission - Rural Local Bodies-Anchalic Panchayats and 13 moderately favorable schemes - Mahila Kishan Sashaktikaran Pariyojana (MKSP), Deen Dayal Upadhyaya Grameen Kaushalya Yojana (DDU-GKY), Rural Self Employment Training Institute (RSETI), etc. and 20 neutral schemes. The sub-domains broadly include - enhance environment awareness (government, youth, educational institutions, communities), disaster management resilience, sustainable housing and infrastructure, sustainable livelihoods, water management & ground water conservation, sustainable waste management, including e-waste addressing climate change adaptation and environment and sustainability broad domain.

12. Power (Electricity) Department

  The department has 1 highly favorable scheme - 1000 MW Solar Power Plants under Mukhyamantri Soura Shakti Prakalpa, 2 moderately favorable schemes focused on enhancing the intra-state transmission system (AEGCL & APGCL), and four neutral schemes. These initiatives contribute to broad domains of climate mitigation and environmental sustainability. The sub-domains broadly include - renewable energy promotion, reducing pollution and GHG emissions, advancing public transport (EVs), disaster resilience, and environmental awareness.

13. Public Works Buildings and National Highways Department

  A highly favourable scheme due to use of environment friendly construction materials, promotion of culture and tourism leading to a healthy society. The 15 moderately favourable schemes include Buildings (Public Works)-Siu-Ka-Pha Samannaya Kshetra (Tied ACA/ SPA), Construction of High School at Tea Garden etc., and there are 8 neutral schemes. The department is focusing on addressing all the three broad domains viz. Climate Change Adaptation, Climate Change Mitigation and Environment and Sustainability. The sub- domains broadly include - sustainable housing and infrastructure, reduction of pollution and Green House Gas (GHG) emissions, reduction of mortality and morbidity from climate change (impact on health) and knowledge building (sensitisation, capacity building, training and skill development).

28

14. []Public Health Engineering Department

  The department has 9 highly favourable, 15 moderately favourable and 8 neutral schemes with focus on climate change mitigation and climate change adaptation aspects. The sub-domains broadly include - sustainable waste management, including e-waste, water management & ground water conservation, disaster management (including flood resilience) response, sustainable livelihoods, reduction of pollution and Green House Gas (GHG) emissions, promotion of renewable energy - Solar/ Hydro / Wind / Bio.

15. Public Works (Roads) Department

  The department has 2 Highly favourable schemes - Assam Disaster Resilient Hill Area Road Development Project and Assam Resilient Rural Bridge Program, 3 moderately favourable schemes -Construction of Roads in Tea Garden Labour Lines, Mukhya Mantrir (Chief Minister's) Mathauri Pakikaran Achani, and 15 neutral schemes. The sub-domains include - water management & ground water conservation, disaster management resilience, sustainable housing and infrastructure focusing on climate adaptation domain.

16. Revenue and Disaster Management Department

  The department has 1 highly favourable scheme - Capacity Building for Disaster Response- which aims to strengthen disaster management, flood resilience, and disaster response. The broad sub-domains include - capacity building, sensitisation, training, and skill development, aligning with the broader domain of environment and sustainability.

17. Science, Technology and Climate Change Department

  The department has 12 highly favorable schemes, including Research and Development, Popularisation of Science – Climate Cell, Maina Parijat, Aryabhatta Science Centre (Block Level), and Bio-resource Centres. Additionally, it is implementing six moderately favorable schemes, such as Bio-Technology Park – Incentive under Biotechnology Policy and Mentoring Programme (CM’s Bigyan Pratibha Sandhan), along with 11 neutral schemes. These initiatives contribute to climate adaptation and environmental sustainability, addressing key sub- domains such as sustainable livelihoods, sustainable agriculture and irrigation, promotion of renewable energy (solar, hydro, wind, bio), knowledge building (sensitisation, capacity building, training, skill development), forest and tree cover enhancement, biodiversity conservation, pollution and GHG emissions reduction, environmental awareness, soil conservation, and temperature variation mitigation.

18. Soil Conservation Department

  The department has 16 highly favourable schemes and 1 neutral scheme focusing on the broad domains of climate change adaptation and environment and sustainability. The sub-domains broadly include - soil conservation, preventing erosion and siltation, water management & ground water conservation, sustainable agriculture and irrigation, reduction of temperature variation, enhanced forest and tree cover and prevention of biodiversity loss.

19. Transport Department

  The department has 4 highly favourable schemes viz. Viability Gap for E-Vehicles, A.S.T.C.- Charging Station for E-Vehicles, Development/ Upgradation of Depot etc., 2 moderately favourable scheme viz. Road Safety staff-Installation. These schemes fall under the broad domains of Climate Change Adaptation and Environment and Sustainability focusing on sub- domains of reducing pollution and greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, as well as sustainable waste management, including e-waste.

20. Tourism Department

  The department has 4 highly favourable and 2 moderately favourable schemes - Amaar Aalohi Rural Homestay Scheme and Tourist facilitation in Ambubachi & similar other occasions innovative religious and cultural tourism promotion activities and 13 neutral schemes. The sub-domains broadly include sustainable waste management, including e-waste and sustainable livelihoods under the broad domain of climate change adaptation.

21. Water Resources Department

  The department has 5 highly favourable schemes such as Rejuvenation of Kollong River, Assam Integrated Flood & River Bank Erosion Risk Management Investment Programme – Assam Integrated River Basin Management Project, Brahmaputra Flood and Riverbank Erosion Risk Management Project – Climate Resilience, Brahmaputra Integrated Flood and Riverbank Erosion Risk Management Project (CRBFRERMP) funded by ADB etc. The sub-domains broadly include water management & groundwater conservation, preventing erosion and siltation, disaster management (including flood resilience and response).

22. Women and Child Development Department

  The department has six highly favourable schemes, including the Special Nutrition Programme and Scheme for Adolescent Girls (SAG). Additionally, there are three moderately favourable schemes, such as the Implementation of the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) Scheme, along with six neutral schemes. The sub-domains broadly include reducing mortality and morbidity caused by climate change impacts on health and promoting sustainable livelihoods with climate adaptation as the broad domain.
